Praefatio.	Here is the translation:
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After completing this book for you, my sons, and finishing the last part of the science of medicine with its completion, and following its explanations and declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of operation, namely surgery with hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Because the operation with hand is lying prostrate in our region and time, and entirely private until perhaps it will perish along with its knowledge, and the track of it will be cut off: and there are left from it only small descriptions in ancient books which have been altered by hands: and errors and hesitation occur to them until their intentions are closed and the power of it is gone. It seemed to me that I should bring it back to life with the arrangement of this Treatise in accordance with the method of position, declaration, and abbreviation: and that I may come along with the forms of iron instruments Cauterii and other tools of the work: when it happens through the addition of declaration and due proportion which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	But the reason why a good craftsman of that kind is not found with his own hand in our present time is: because the art of medicine is long and requires its author to be exercised beforehand in the science of anatomy, as Galenus narrated, until he knows the benefits of members, and their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, tendons, and their number, and their exit and return, and the pulsating and quiet veins, and the exit places of those.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And on account of that, Hippocrates said that a name with a name is much, and with work it is little, and especially in the art of hands.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	But we have already spoken about him at the introduction to this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Because whoever is not knowing what we have said about anatomy does not escape, but rather falls into error, by which people are killed: just as I have seen many of those who claim to be knowledgeable in this science, and boast about it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What happened was that I saw a stupid doctor cut open a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck and lacerate some arteries in her neck. Therefore the woman's blood flowed until she fell dead under his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who presumed to remove a stone from an old man's bladder, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore came to him and removed it with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself had already been called to remove it; and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who was receiving payment from a certain Duke of our land in exchange for his medicine; and it happened to the black eunuch who was with him that he broke his leg near the heel. And the doctor hastened with his ignorance, and bound the fracture over the wound with poultices, and bandages tightly tightened, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his own desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	After that he let him go after a few days and ordered him not to loosen the bandage; and it stood thus until his leg and foot became gangrened and he came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called to him; and I hastened to loosen the bandage; and as a result there was calmness, and he was delivered from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, corruption had already set in on the member; and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	So the corruption ceased to spread through the member until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who pierced a cancerous abscess; and it ulcerated after some days until its evil quality was greatly magnified with his lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	What is this? Because when the cancer is pure from melancholic humor, then it should not be approached at all with iron, unless it is in a member that can tolerate it, so that the whole of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, oh sons, it is necessary for you to know that the operation is divided into two divisions with hand: namely, an operation which is accompanied by salvation, and an operation where there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already stirred up everywhere in this book, where the operation comes, in which there is fear and trembling.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of this and leave it alone, lest foolish people find a way to speak and be ashamed.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore take measurement with solicitude and protection, and treat your weak patients with ease and firmness, and use the better way leading to salvation and praiseworthy succession through the grace of God; and leave off dreadful griefs difficult to cure: and lift up your souls from that which makes you fear, so that hesitation may enter upon you in your faith and advantage.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining for your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your possessions.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galenus indeed said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You will not heal bad illness: lest you be called evil doctors.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	However, I have now divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Concerning cauterization with fire and cauterization with sharp medicine, divided and arranged from head to feet, and the forms of instruments and tools of cauterization, and all that is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Concerning section and perforation, bleeding and ventosities, wounds: and extracting arrows and similar ones: and the whole chapter, arranged in forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Concerning restoration, and dislocation, and cure of twisting, and similar ones: chaptered, arranged from head to feet, and in forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Chapter on the Use and Harm of Cautery: and to which complexions it is suitable, and at what time; and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before that, I must first recall the nature of its usefulness and harm, and in which complexion it is exhibited.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse on the quality of the usefulness and harm of Cautery is a lengthy and subtle one, requiring knowledge and hidden secrets.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And many wise men have spoken on this subject and disagreed among themselves. And as for me, I am content with a little of their words, fearing prolongation.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore that Cautery agrees with all complexions, both those with matter and those without matter, except for two complexions which are hot without matter and dry without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	But in the complexions of heat and dryness with matter, they disagreed among themselves.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some have said that Cautery is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others have said the opposite of this, namely that Cautery is not suitable in an illness which arises from heat and dryness; for since fire's nature is heat, it is incongruous to heal a hot and dry illness with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And the one who said the opposite of this has said that through Cautery a benefit is achieved in every hot and dry illness which occurs in human bodies; for when you compare the body of a man and his humors to the complexion of fire, you find the body of a man to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself say this through his discourse; because through experience it has revealed itself to me on several occasions.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not proper that someone should come to attend to that unless he has already been tested and trained in the last exercise of Cauterization, and has known the diversity of human temperaments, and the disposition of illnesses within themselves, and their causes, and accidents, and the time span of these.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	But there is no fear for the other temperaments from you, especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For now all physicians have agreed on these matters and do not disagree with cauterization in treating them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, children, that from the secret of healing by means of cauterization with fire and the excellence of it combined with medicine that burns: because fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the part that is being cauterized, and does not harm another connected member unless a small harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of the medicine that burns reaches what is distant from the member, and perhaps makes an illness of difficult healing occur in another member, and perhaps kills it.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do that unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	And now it has become known to us through experience, because of the length of service and study with art, and standing on the truth of things: and because of that, I excuse myself from the length of discourse.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not so, because it is not allowed to this book of mine, I would reveal to you the secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in expelling diseases from bodies, by which it drives out illnesses through philosophical demonstration, which would be clarified in your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, children, that they themselves disagree on the time when it is proper to perform cauterization, and hold that a better time is that of truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is fitting at any time: therefore, because the harm that occurs due to time is submerged in the benefit that is attracted with cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cauterizing instrument is for pains that are necessary, strong, and stubborn, which do not tolerate delay: therefore, because one fears from them that a greater harm may occur than slight damage done during the time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not fall into your minds, my sons, that which is not esteemed by those people and foolish doctors, namely, that the illness which is cured through cauterization does not always return: and they place this consequence, and it is not as they think. Therefore, because cauterization is not, except in place of medicine, which alters the complexion and exhausts the humors that are the causes why pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization is superfluous over medicine because of the speed and power of its own operation and the intensity of its dominion: and it is possible that illness returns after some time, according to the complexion of the infirm person, and the location of their illness, and the power of its cause: and what is prepared in their body from an accumulation of excesses within them: and what reaches them through food and similar things from their causes, unless there is a condition where cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle illness in a few excesses and humors of the member, such as tooth cauterization for pain, and similar ones, it is possible that the pain does not return in that one.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the common people's talk is again, that cauterization is the last resort of medicine, and their speech is correct: not with regard to what they intend in it; because they believe that there is no cure which compares with medicine, nor with anything else after the application of cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the thing itself is contrary to that and their intention, because cauterization is the last resort of medicine not because when we administer modes of healing in some illness, and those medicines do not help: then we administer cauterization at the end of things, and it helps; so it becomes clear that cauterization is the last resort of medicine, not according to the understanding which the common people and many foolish doctors have.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients have said that a cauterium with gold is better than one with iron: and they did not say this unless for the equality of gold and the subtlety of its substance. And they said that a cauterium does not make pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	However, this is not absolutely true: for I have already tested it and found that it does not do so in certain bodies without other things.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cauterium with this is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you put the cauterium with gold into fire, it is not revealed to you how much heat you want, because of the redness of the gold: and when it's cooling down, and if you add more ignition on top of it, it melts in the fire and turns into plates.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls into occupation with that, and because of this, we make a cauterium with iron for ourselves faster and closer to the operation, according to its straightness.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I myself have already arranged this chapter on cauterium according to chapters: and I arranged it from head to foot, so that the one seeking may find what they want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Chapter On the Method of Cauterizing the Head at the Crown Commisure.
Caput II.	Book Two.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here cauterization serves to counteract the dominance of moisture and coldness over the brain: which two are causes of swelling, and the abundance of fluid flux from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and the abundance of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain: and universally all kinds of illnesses that occur due to coldness, such as paralysis, swelling, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar ones among those illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is that you precede the patient by administering a purgative medicine to cleanse the head for three nights or four, according to how much the patient's strength requires, and their age, and their habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then tell him to make his head bald with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands square, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with an inkstone.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then apply the olive cauter to fire, which has this shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with an inkstone, while you slowly withdraw your hand and turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly lift up your left hand and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	What if you see that a quantity of bone from the skull or a quantity of zeuberi has already been exposed, then lift up your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat with the same iron or another one that is not chilled; until you see the bones which I told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something from salt and dissolve it in water, and pour it on the wound, and put it over the place; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put the soaked cotton on top of the butter, and leave it over the place until the scab is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for that with the ointment of tetrapharmakon, until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that the more a wound remains open, the more pus is emitted; therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone, and the cautery held until something thickened like bone is burnt.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then scrape off after what has been burned away from the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary to arrive at the end with a cautery, so that it impresses on the bone an imprint like a form of kyrate: or an instrument which women put in infusion of small letters, and they think that vapors of the head escape from this place, and that the wound remains open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it will be treated until it is consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But to me these two species of cauterization seem to be entirely useless except in certain people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And it is better for him to leave with his own safety than to be treated by me.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, just as we have testified in other limbs; and especially when an invalid's head is naturally weak. And indeed, the first species of cauterization is more safe and better for me to use, and I employ it: therefore I will work with it for the sake of salvation.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	On the manner of cauterizing the head when the whole head is in pain.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a chronic pain occurs throughout the whole head and it is prolonged in an invalid, and he uses herbs, and poultices, and purgatives, and oils, and embrocations.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with one cauterization, which we have narrated, and brings him no relief from those things: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if an invalid's head is strong and natural, and not weak, and it finds a moderate coldness: then cauterize with another cauterization under that slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over the whole horn of his own head with a cauterization, so that it does not penetrate the skin and opens up from the bone the quantity which we have narrated.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one cauterization at the back of his own head, in the place which is called the "vas": and this is the location where the "ventosa" is placed; and elevate your mat there, and do not open up the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For an invalid finds that because of this pain is very intense and different from the pains of all other cauterizations on the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will say this about the Cauterion in its place; and it is necessary that it be a cauterization by which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of his head is cauterized more finely with a cauterization by which the middle part of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterizing in a headache, both with burnt medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occur on the head, or when the pain extends to the eye, and the head is cleansed with purging medicines, and the rest of the treatment, which I mentioned in the divisions of afflictions, is administered, but that does not provide a complete cure: then cauterization is done in this case by two methods: either with medicine that burns sharply, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cauterization with sharp-burning medicine is this: you take a single tooth of garlic, and peel it, and cut off its ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then divide the painful area with a broad lancet at the proper time, until there is a spot beneath the skin where the tooth is captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it into the spot beneath the skin until it is hidden: then tie a cloth over it with a gentle constriction and let it be for fifteen hours. Then release it, extract the garlic, and let it sit for two or three days afterwards. Afterwards, place a poultice submerged in butter on top of it until the area becomes pus-filled. Then care for it with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with some burning medicines which I wrote about in the 12th treatise, On Blistering Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	The cauterization of it with iron is done according to this method.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Fire Cautery, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Clavilis, because the form of its head is like the form of a hook, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it is a small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it over the spot and hold your hand steady. And you should turn the iron slowly with speed, and let the part that is burned be as thick as the skin's middle portion.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift up your hand so that the artery which is below is not burned, and a flow of blood may occur.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the cloth in salt water and place it on the spot, and leave it for three days. Then put the cloth with butter; afterwards care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this headache with the extremity of a second-edged cauterizing knife.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of cutting into an artery in this headache, not properly old-fashioned.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in ancient headache.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating a headache, following what we said earlier in the previous treatment and in the divisions of illnesses, and the cure does not help: and you see from the illness that what we said about the first cauterization with medicine or with fire is not enough for him, then it is necessary to use the Ignias Cauterium with a knife, until it becomes white after you have marked above the place of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger or so: and put your hand on one side, and tie it tight until you cut into the artery and reach the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to beware of the continuation of the jawbone which moves during mastication, lest it be burned or the nerve that moves it, whereby a spasms may occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be on guard and take care to prevent bleeding from the severed artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is fear in its severing, and especially for one who is ignorant of what he is doing, and not studious or experienced: and he abandons the operation at once.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with a reminder of the regulation of bleeding from an artery according to its own manner, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see that from sickness a wound is not being healed by this cautery, and you see the sick person bearing with patience the cautery in the middle of their head, just as we have narrated, then treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the cautery that we mentioned in the chapter on extracting an artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cautery is better and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the manner of cauterizing in earache.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear due to cold and is cured with salves and the rest of the treatment we mentioned in the division, but the pain does not depart, then apply the fire cautery: and that is what is called a Point, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make the point with it after its ignition on the entire circumference of the ear, as it revolves; or on the circumference of both, if the pain is simultaneously present in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And stretch out with the cautery from the root of the ear for a little bit, after you have marked the places with wax: and let the length of the cautery be ten points on each ear, and so forth.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then cure the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the manner of cauterizing in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture that is cured by cauterization is not excepting those species which occur from phlegm, according to what we mentioned in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And having applied the cautery to the species that occurs from dryness and nervous spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this species of torture with hyssop, and powdering the head, and gargling, and your treatment does not bring relief, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient three times: one at the root of the ear, and a second a little lower than that, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterizer on the contrary side of the weaker part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Because softening does not occur unless it happens in a part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize it directly at the tip of the upper ear, a little below the horn of the head: and afterwards, as long as the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cauterizer until it burns a quantity equal to the thickness of half the skin.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cauterizer, and it is a kind of small knife, whose shape is as follows: although it is not much finer than what you see: and it should be so that the knife is a little above the excessive thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with what preceded: until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in Ancient Apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When ancient apoplexy sets in and you treat it as we have said, and your treatment does not take effect, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize him with four cauterizers on top of his entire head, and one in the middle of his head, as we have said, and another at the back of his head, according to what has preceded: and the manner of cauterizing is according to what has preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	And also cauterize with the cauterizer above the mouth of the stomach: and this is the final one.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat it as what preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the manner of cauterizing in Oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the drink of the first patient, there should be given great hyena and purifying pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then quickly dress the entire head of the patient and place on the back of his head an ointment made from vinegar, as described in the treatise on ointments: and place it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the correct method of cauterization; and do that in the same order as I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If it is then healed through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make three cauterizations on the back of his head, which are descended from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; and put between every cauterization the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the cauterization with what preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish to add more and he is weak and endures this: then make a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	What if you want to add more: then cauterize it above both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for it until it is healed: and make the cauterization with oil according to the form that was previously mentioned.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	About the way of cauterizing in Paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Head X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	You should proceed with the cleansing of the head with hyssop and with what we said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the infirm person: afterwards cauterize it with a cauterization in the middle of the head, and a cauterization above every horn of the head, and a cauterization above the back of it, and three over the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	But if you are desirous of a remedy for the softening of the body and the infirm person endures it and the illness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauterizations above the vertebrae of the back, and the last one along with a cauterization, until most of it is burned off from the skin, and lift up your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for him until he is healed: and thus anoint with oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	About the way of cauterizing in Epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Head XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized unless he whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, it is necessary that you cleanse his brain first with myrrh and with the other cure which we mentioned in the division; when he is very weak or is enduring in the acceptance of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	However, if it is a child who does not tolerate medicines, then a gargling substance and cleansing chewings are administered to purify the brain, many days beforehand with the improvement of food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then quickly shave his head, afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what has gone before; and another cautery on the back of his head, and above all the horn of his own head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and tolerates it, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I mentioned in the case of paralysis, and softening of the body on the vertebrae of the neck and back; and let the cautery be olive oil according to the method that went before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the patient is a child, then place a subtle cautery according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	Of the manner of cauterizing in Melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries which we mentioned in the case of paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is excessiveness tending towards melancholy, and the body of the patient is humid and weakened, then give him to drink what will purify his brain, according to what went before in the division: afterwards quickly shave the head of the patient, and make a bandage after that, well-made from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the patient sitting square, be held firmly by all parts.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more worthy from old sheep's butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm him over a fire with tempered heat measurement, as much as his finger can tolerate when it is inserted into him.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then remove him from the middle of his head, in a circle, and let him be until he cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Make that to every infirm person once a week, with his entire regimen being good, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cautery him by making small punctures on most of his body, except that you will hold your hand with the cautery, and so it smells.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place a poultice that has been soaked in butter or goose fat on top of him.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	Of the manner of cauterying in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you are shown the principle of water in the eye by signs, as I said in division, then begin and pour the patient with what cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And watch over him from all moistures, and make him sit in a bath on several days of fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to shave his head and cautery him in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cautery him above both temples with two cauteries, if there is an onset of water flowing down from both eyes simultaneously: or from one side only, if there is an onset of water flowing down from one eye: and cut off with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in breadth equal to the temples: and beware of blood flow.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	And if you see anything from that, then cut him off immediately with any medicine possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting off, and caution against blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauteryed on the neck, under two bones, with two final cauteries produced.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	Here is the translation:
Caput XIIII.	Here is the translation:
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and frequent: and they are above the veins and arteries which are visible on the outer surface of the head, it is verified that this is from excesses of cold and phlegmatic things. Then cauterize with the same cauterization that I described in the beginning of the flowing water, cauterizing in the middle of the head, and two cauterizations above the temples, and two cauterizations on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if there is need of addition, then cauterize it on all sides cautiously around the eye, above the outer corner of the eyebrow with a small cauter.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the manner of cauterizing in nasal discharge.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating that with what we said in the division, and the treatment does not agree: then hasten and give three infusions of vinegar to drink for three nights. Then gently massage his head, and cauterize it with a medium cauterization, with olive oil cauterization.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with the cauterizer of nails, two cauterizations, above the two eyebrows under the hair a little.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And keep away from the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the nail cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the manner of cauterizing for relaxing the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is relaxed from illness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cauterization, with lunar cauterization.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauterizations on all sides: and draw back from the two temples: and let the length of the entire cauterization be according to the length of the eyebrow: and do not leave your hand with the cauterizer, but rather according to the quantity that is burned off the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this lunar mode of cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	About the manner of cauterizing the eyelid when the eyebrows are turned backwards and pierce the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is in this case according to two modes: either a burning cautery with fire; or a burning cautery with medicinal combustion.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	However, in the burning cautery with fire, first instruct the patient beforehand to remove their hair if they are one of those who pluck it, until it is lengthened and equalized.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if they prick him at the beginning of his growth: then bind up his eyes with a bandage, so that they may not be moved until they are developed.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are developed and equalized, then place the patient's head in your bosom: afterwards mark on the eyelid of his eyes with encaustic, marking it so that it is according to the shape of a myrtle leaf; and let the beginning of the mark be near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place the cooled cautery in white of egg or in psillium mucus on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then set fire to the cautery, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize above the figure which you marked gradually in many places, until the surface of the skin, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, appears properly.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the success of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted and the hairs raised at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So lift up your hand then, and let him go three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place on top of it a compress with butter, until the scab is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with ointment, until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	What if some hair returns after an hour and the eyelid becomes soft: then repeat the cauterization over that place, just as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however hairs are on the lower part: then cauterize it, until it is raised to its natural place: and it will be equal so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the way of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is necessary to make a person take out the hairs until they are lengthened and equalized.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from cloth of linen the shape of a mulberry leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and from unimbibed chalk one ounce or almost that much: then mix them together with good rubbing and make it quickly, so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread it over the cloth which you made in the shape of a mulberry leaf, and place it on the eyelid of one eye, or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place it under the eye a poultice soaked in egg white: and the head of the sick person be in your bosom.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger on top of the medicine, and press it a little bit.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move it as often as the sick person feels the bite of the medicine, because its biting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore this biting which he finds continues, then let go of the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the biting ceases, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider if you see the eyelid lifted, just as it is lifted with contraction by fire or incision, and that is good: and if not, then repeat over it with medicine on a different place where the medicine does not imprint and does not leave a mark, until your operation is equalized and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place over it a poultice with butter, until the burned skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with diaphanic ointment or another, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you to keep watch during the operation, so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	And if the eyelid becomes soft after a few days and something from the hair enters the eye, then apply medicine to that area which becomes soft because of the eyelid itself, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that human eyes differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, your consideration should be according to this: and the path of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a zeal for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Of the manner of cauterizing in the tear duct.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you cure the tear duct as we have said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not bring relief: then it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to put their head in your shoulder, and have a servant hold their head between your hands in such a way that it is not moved or agitated with their head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place the infused caustic in the white of the eye, or on the mucus of psillium above their eye: then apply fire to the cauterization, which has this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the shape of a vulture's feather cane, from one end with which the cauterization is made: and if you wish it to penetrate up to the other extremity, and if you wish it to go up in such a way, then try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this concave shape is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the tear duct, if it is open, and drain the pus from it, and dry out the duct itself: and if it is not open, then open it, and drain its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place a cauterizer on top of it which becomes very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand near the cauterizer at the eye, towards the nose, so that your hand does not stray or disturb the patient; and place the cauterizer on the fatty part of the eyelid, and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you then reach to the beginning of your cauterizer all the way up to the mouth, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat your cauterizer once or twice, as needed; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a poultice with butter, and care for it with a drying ointment, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if it has passed forty days and is not healed: then place a sharp corrosive medicine on top of it, until the mouth is uncovered; and scrape it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some first ones said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Approach the place of the fistula and find it; then place in that opening a fine cannula, namely, a thin tube, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of a drachma from molten lead; and hold your hand with good retention on the cannula, so that the patient is not moved at all, nor does he run or bring the molten lead to his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you place a poultice infused with egg white or water on top of the patient's eye.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the location of the fistula and cures it with a wondrous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	And if the fistula is healed, as we said by cauterization and cure, that is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer the nostril and guide the fistula back into its natural course through the nose, according to what comes in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the manner of cauterizing lip fissures.
Caput XX.	Chapter Twenty.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many times, fissures occur on the lip which are called "Pili", and especially on the lips of boys.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you are treating these fissures as we said in the division of diseases, and the treatment does not agree, then take a small cauterizing instrument, fashioned thus.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the fineness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the burning instrument hastily into the very fissures until the cauter reaches to the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with cerate, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the manner of cauterizing mouth abscesses.
Caput XXI.	Chapter Twenty-One.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an apostema occurs at the root of a tooth, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then pus forms and bursts forth: afterwards it becomes corrupted, and the pus runs and forms an abscess: then you should care for it, and the treatment does not agree in this case, then it is necessary that you take a cauterizing fire according to its size, which fits into the abscess.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the burning instrument into the orifice of the abscess, and hold your hand, until the hot iron reaches to its depth and end: do that once, or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards, as we said about the treatment until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the abscess is lanced and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the corrupted bone according to what will come its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the manner of cauterizing gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter Twenty-Two.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum becomes softened due to humidity and the teeth are moved, and you care for it with medicines, but it does not agree: then place the head of the sick person on your shoulder.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply the cauterizing tool, which will be shaped as follows, so that you place a cannula on top of the tooth: and insert into it the hot cauterized tool quickly: and hold your hand for a moment, until the patient feels the heat of the fire has already reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift up your hand: then repeat the cauterizing tool several times, as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then have the patient fill their mouth with saltwater and hold it for one hour: and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened by movement, and the softened gum is tightened, and the corrupted moisture is dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the manner of cauterizing teeth in pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is caused by coldness, either there is coldness itself or worms, and treatment does not help with medicines: then cauterization is done in that place according to two methods: either with butter or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	However, the cauterization of it with butter is, that you take goat's butter and boil it in an iron kettle or on a brazier.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a cloth and wrap it around the end of the finger.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then submerge the cloth in the boiled butter: and place it on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools down: then repeat it several times, until the heat of fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you want, immerse a wool or cloth in cold butter, and place it on the painful tooth: and place a hot iron on top of it, until the fire reaches the depth of the tooth cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization with fire is, that you direct the hot cauterizing tool to a bronze or iron cannula.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something thick in his body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the patient's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take the cauterizer, which will have this form, and place it above that tooth; and hold your hand until the cauterizer becomes cool.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do that several times, for the pain will be removed, either on that same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary when the cauterizer makes an impression on that tooth, for the sick person to fill their mouth with good betony and hold it there for one hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterizer.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever extremity you have possible; and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	Chapter on the method of cauterizing in strophules.
Caput XXIIII.	Book XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the strophules are caused by phlegm and cold humidity, and they do not obey digestion through medicines, and you wish to hasten their digestion: then take a concave cauterizer with this form.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that smoke may come out at the cauterizer from the other extreme; and place it ignited once upon the swelling, and again if you need it, until it reaches to the depth of the swelling.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the swelling is small, then place the cauterizer according to the size of the swelling.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and place on top of it a poultice infused in butter until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with tooth ointment, until the form of the cannula heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	Chapter on the method of cauterizing in hoarseness of voice and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Book 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moistures overcome the canal of the lungs, and especially when this is accompanied by coldness of complexion, then it is necessary that the sick person be purged first with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.
