Then cauterize him at the back of the throat, near the root of the tongue, in a depressed place; and beware, lest with the cautery you reach the throat or skin, except for a little bit of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize him with another cautery at the junction of the neck, at the very end of his spine; and let the cautery be a nail, according to the manner that preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what came before, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the manner of cauterizing in chest ailments and coughs.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and chest distress are from cold moistures, and the patient does not have fever or consumption, nor is it an old affliction; then cauterize him with two cauteries above the shoulder blade in depressed, soft, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize him with another one in the middle of the chest between two breasts; and let the cautery be a pipe-shaped one, according to the manner that came before.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish, make your cautery by pricking with the instrument called Punctum, whose form preceded in piercing pain of ears; and let the pricks be from thirty to almost sixty.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what came before, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why should one be alleviated with him when you do with him a series of three cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the manner of cauterizing in Titillicus, in dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the humerus is displaced due to moisture and does not return to its place within an hour from the start of displacement, until it becomes his habit of returning, then; afterwards it is displaced by a small motion which happens as we have already testified, then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation at first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the patient should be placed supine on his back, or on a healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift the scalp, which is inside the tentorium, upwards with your left hand's fingers; and if the joint dislocation occurs towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take a cauterizing instrument with two handles.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the scalp until it penetrates to the other side and a figure of cauterization appears with four caustics.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes a cauterization is made with a cauterizing instrument having three handles, and so a figure of cauterization appears then with six caustics; and the handles are according to the subtlety of the net.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the shape of the cauterizing instrument having three handles.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one more is added to this method, and so there are eight caustics.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place crushed thorns with salt on top of the cauterizer.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make sure the patient remains calm and quiet so that the limb does not move at any time until it is comforted.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is above, and this rarely occurs, then cauterize it on top of the shoulder with a cauterizing instrument having a hinge, or with multiple small punctures.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened, and moisture is removed: and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	Of the method of cauterizing the Stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When coldness and moisture occur in the Stomach, to such a degree that they extract it from its natural balance, and multiply catarrhs towards it, and constant methods of treatment do not benefit: then it is necessary for the patient to be placed supine on his back, and stretch out his legs and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three caustics, the first being under the ear of the breast as long as the first finger, and having a hinge; and two below, on both sides of one caustic, until a triangular figure of caustics appears.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And stretch between both so that they may not join together when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be the quantity of three thicknesses of skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the shape of the cauteries be according to this form without addition; and if you wish, apply a great cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let the cautery which makes this cautery be one according to the shape of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by piercing it with one who is terrified by this cautery; and thus signs are made above the stomach at the point according to the quantity you wish with an encaustic: then cauterize it with a puncture cautery: then care for it with the cure that preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing the hypochondrium cold.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens that in the hypochondrium there is pain from cold and moisture, or from a thick cough, until the patient's natural excretion proceeds excessively and is cured with what we said, but does not benefit him: then it is necessary for the patient to be placed on his back, and three cauteries with an encaustic are marked according to this figure, and of the same quantity above the lower hypochondrium, where a man's elbow reaches: and let there be space between each cautery equal to the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be straight according to the length of the body; and do not press your hand much with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of what is burned be the thickness of skin, the middle part of it not added; and let the patient stand over his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if he is not standing, then let him lie down, who has already stretched out his legs and lifted up his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you, that you may cauterize these wounds with a cauterizing knife, when subtlety and prudence are with you in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And take care that you do not proceed too late in cauterizing, and that the thickness of the skin is thoroughly burnt, so that the body is thoroughly burnt and reaches to the intestines; for the skin there is thin, therefore know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the manner of cauterizing apostumes of the Apis.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When it happens that exitura occurs, and you wish to know if the aposteme is in the flesh of the Apis, or in its tunic; then if it is in the flesh of the Apis, it invades with a pitiful pain, and gravity without sharpness: and if it is in the tunic of the Apis, there is sharp pain with vehemence: and you see now that its cure has fatigued its physicians.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore the patient must lean back over his own neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then place the figure of the aposteme with an encaustum; then apply fire to the cauter that is likened to a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with that cauter one, until the skin is thoroughly burned and reaches to the siphac, until all pus has gone forth; then care for it with a cure of exiturata, until it is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not right for this kind of cauterizing to be used, unless the study in the art of medicine is prolonged in him; and through whose hands these diseases concur with some experiment several times: then indeed he may dare to undertake this operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But rather to leave it, that is better with me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the manner of cauterizing in Pleuresis.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients have said that a cauter with the roots of Aristolochia should be used for a cold Pleuresis in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is, that you take from the dried roots of Aristolochia long ones, one root longer than those which are found from it, and let it be like the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil, and burn it with fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize it with a cautery one on the spot where the wing of the jawbone meets the neck, and two small cauteries slightly declined under the guilezzi slightly to the side towards the part that is below the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And two small cauteries also on the spot where it is between the fifth and sixth ribs slightly declined towards the back a little bit; and another cautery in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from the back: one on the spot where it is between two spoon-shaped bones; and two small cauteries from both sides of the chest, with the lower one being in the spot between two spoon-shaped bones.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not fitting for you to press your hand with the cautery, rather let it be in plain sight, smoldering on the surface of the skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And now some ancient people have said that there are men who use a cautery made of iron similar to a ray: and they heat it, and insert it into the spot between the ribs, until they reach with it to the abscess itself, and let the pus exit: just as we said in the case of apostema Epatis.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this operation with the cautery there is a risk, that either the sick person dies immediately, or an opening occurs in the place of a fistula, for which there is no cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Of the manner of cauterizing the Spleen Chapter 32.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating the sickness of the spleen, as we said in the division of sicknesses, and your treatment does not take effect, then there is a cautery in it according to three modes, all of which are straight.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of which is, that you make three or four cauteries, lining them up according to the length of the spleen, following the figure of the cauteries of Epatis, whose preceding figure we have described.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be among all cauterization a quantity of thickness equal to that of a finger, or somewhat more.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the mode of cauterization be as we said it should be for cauterizing the liver.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not compress your hand with the cauter, and let the patient lie weakly on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cauterization is: that the cauter having two prongs, as we said in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder, you raise the skin which is directly above the spleen, where the patient's left arm lies; and let your elevation be such as to elevate the skin according to the breadth of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two fiery prongs deeply into the skin, until they penetrate to the other side; then withdraw the cauter; thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a cauter having three prongs.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cauter after you have released it, allowing it to discharge pus over many days; for this is more beneficial than any preceding treatment in the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	Of the method of cauterizing in Hydrocephalus.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	A cauter does not fall into Hydrocephalus unless it is properly applied.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating Hydrocephalus with the methods of treatment which we mentioned in the division, and the treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize it four times around the navel, and one cauter above the stomach, and one cauter above the liver, and two cauteris after the spine between the vertebrae, and one on the direct of the breast, and another on the direct of the stomach; and let the quantity of depth of the cauter be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then release the cauter open, so that it may discharge pus over a long period of time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the sick person from treatment after cauterization with him, because it is necessary that two intentions congregate to him; and healing will hasten to him with God's help.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cauterizer with which the belly is cauterized should be a key; according to its shape: and that with which the back is cauterized, should be olive-like, according to its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing Feet, and Legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they apostemate in hydropic and fill with citrine water: it is necessary that you cauterize above the dorsal part of the foot at night, which is between auricular and ankle; and raise your hand with the cauterizer, and do not twist him: then raise your hand: and do not repeat it entirely.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the water citrine will drizzle, and let the cauterizer be according to this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauterizers on both legs, one on each leg, and let the cauterizer be with the edge of a knife-shaped cauterizer; and let it be according to the length of the leg, one below the knee and another above, about in the middle of the leg: and above all the hip, make two cauterizers: and leave the open cauterium without treatment for a long time, until some water drips from it: then cure it with the rest that we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the method of cauterizing in resolving the Abdomen.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a resolution of the belly due to cold and humidity, until the retaining and digestive virtues, which are in the stomach and intestines, are weakened: and it is cured with methods of treatment, but does not heal; and you see the sick person tolerating the cauterizer with excessive vigor, then cauterize him with a great cauterizer above his stomach, according to what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with a circular cauterizer, and four small cauterizers around the navel, with a small key-shaped cauterizer: and a large cauterizer or two over the alcatin above the hips.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive moistures and the patient tolerates them, then cauterize him with a cauter on the breastbone and with another on all his hip; and perhaps add two small cauterizers near the great one on the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For indeed the cure is advancing, whose benefit does not stray.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the manner of cauterizing Hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are old and many hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, which are formed from thick, cold, or corrupted humors, and they are cured as we said in the division, and not by cure: then cauterize three cauterizers on the lower back of the loin a little triangularly under the armpit, and one cauterizer under the navel almost two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cooled and his food is not digested, and you see his face breaking out in boils, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cauterizer, as before; and one on his spleen, and another on his liver, with a small cauterizer: and leave the cauter open for some time: thereafter cure him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the manner of cauterizing altitudes after their removal.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you remove the altitude, then apply a cautery fire that is similar to a ray.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the burning thing into the removed altitude: and your last hand, until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows: do this once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore there are many altitudes, then cauterize each one with a cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then cure them, with that which benefits them from ointments, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a great cauter on alum, it is more beneficial for his sake.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the manner of cauterizing an anal fistula.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When an invalid does not obey the section and operation that we have described in his place, and is terrified by it, perhaps he will be healed with a cauter.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore an abscess occurs to someone, and becomes old, pus flows out of it, and corrupted moisture.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is therefore more noble that what is necessary is that you probe it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the quantity of its depth with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then bring forth the fire-catheter, which is similar to a rod.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert yourself, ignited, into that abscess and note the quantity up to which you have entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And apply the cauter to it again and again, until all those corrupted bodies are burned away, once, twice, or thrice, according to your own necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And be careful not to burn the nerve if it is there, or a great vein; or if the abscess extends to the bladder or to the intestine, then be careful about all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do that unless the abscess is in a fleshy place; and consider, because it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place is sealed and the materials are removed from it, and remains thus for a long time: then you will know that it has already been healed entirely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if the materials are not removed from it, then you will know that it is penetrating, or that there is a corrupted opening deep within it, or almost one of those things, the remembrance of which will come to its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the manner of cauterizing kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Here is the translation:
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When it happens that there is pain in the kidneys from cold or from gross swelling, and it diminishes due to the weakness of the person, then it is necessary to cauterize the area above the membrane over the kidneys, cauterizing both kidneys with a caustic clavicle, the reminder of which precedes.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize it again on that very membrane.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Why three lines?
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore they will be more beneficial for healing.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the manner of cauterizing the Bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When debility and softening occur in the Bladder, caused by cold and moisture, until the infirm person no longer retains urine, then cauterize it on the lower part of the abdomen above the Bladder, where the pubic hairs begin, and with a caustic from the right side of the abdomen, and another from the left side of that; and let the length of this cauterization be according to the size of the thumb's knuckle: and cauterize it with an inferior back caustic, or two caustics if needed: and let it be done as the preceding clavicle caustic.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the manner of cauterizing the Womb.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture occur in the Womb, and they prevent conception through that, and the menses of hers are corrupted, and their promotion is delayed, and pain comes to her at their arrival, then it is necessary to cauterize with three caustics around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and with a caustic on the lower back, or two caustics: and let there be a clavicle caustic.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the manner of cauterizing the Shoulder in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous humidities flow to the socket of the Shoulder, and become the cause of its exit from its place: and the sign of this is that the leg extends over the other when they are brought together; and a vacant space is found at the site of dislocation.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary that you cauterize the patient over the almond-shaped anchor of his own cauterio similar circle. After you have signed with encaustro around the circumference of the almond, as it revolutes; and so that the almond itself falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cauter be one whose shape has preceded in cauterizing the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	But if this cauter is not present to you, then cauterize him with three cauterizations, using the olive-oil cauterio large; and let the depth of the cauterization be according to the thickness of the skin altogether.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	Of the manner of cauterizing in Sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the almond-shaped anchor and there are causes of cold and moisture, and the patient is treated as we said earlier, and the cure does not bring relief, and it becomes old: then it is necessary that you purge the patient from gross humors with foetid pills or with artificial pills, and similar things.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the manner of cauterization in that is according to two modes: either a cauterio with medicines that burn, or a cauterio with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	A cauterio with fire is according to many modes.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of which is that you cauterize over the almond-shaped anchor of his own with three triangular cauterizations, in this shape.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make their depth good or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let the space between every cauterio be the quantity of the thickness of a finger; and let the cauterio be olive-oil.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes, however, it is necessary to make a cauterio in the middle over the head of his own anchor.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Wherefore there are four cauterias.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded in the cauterization of an anchor's dislocation, one by one; so that the circle contains the entire anchor.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the skin entirely.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method for cauterization in sciatica, when the pain clings to the sacrum itself and does not extend as far as the buttock and thigh.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	But if it extends as far as the buttock and thigh, then you should cauterize that place on the buttock with two cauteries, above where the patient complains of pain, and your own cautery on the hollow four fingers deep in the left side: and let the cautery be a knife-like one.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery should be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	But if the patient complains that the pain extends as far as the toes of the foot, then you should cauterize him there where he complains with a punctiform cautery, three, four, or more, as needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if the patient complains of pain being below the knee on the side towards the thigh, then you should cauterize him there with a single knife-like cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware of this in all your cauterizations, that you do not go so far as to burn a nerve or a large artery, and bring harm or constriction upon the patient through it.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I myself have seen one or two of those who had cauterized above the hollow and gone too far in their cauterization, and as a result, the leg has become swollen until it reached the foot, and the whole limb was perforated and corrupted: then there followed dissolution of the bowels and death afterwards.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If pain is present on both sides simultaneously, cauterize both sides in this manner.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said that in the cauterization of the sacrum, this is the method.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a like samai from iron, whose diameter is the middle of a palm: and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of a finger's knuckle, or somewhat less: and within that samai, put another samai.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be space that is between all the bones as much as the width of a thumb's knuckle: and let the bones be open on both sides: and let their height be almost like a knot, or two knots: and make for them an armband from iron carefully fitted into the bones.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it should be ignited in the fire until it reddens and emits sparks: then it should be placed over a mortar anvil for an invalid or weak person to lean on, resting against a healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore, burn him with three round cauterizations on one side.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let it be released after three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards, apply ointments with butter: and let the wound remain open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with an ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says: We have not used this type of cauterization much, because of the terror inspired by its appearance: and therefore, we have found few who dare to wait above it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Yet it is one of the good cauterizations for him who suffers, and finds a place with it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	However, this cauterization with burning medicines is such that you make two bones having a perforated armband, into which the hinge of its gate descends from air or iron, of equal length to the wall: whose height will be two knots, or almost as big as themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be space that is between each one as much as the thickness of a finger, and let them be open below and above: and let them be such that they contain themselves together, according to this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it over a mortar anvil, for an invalid lying on their healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand firmly onto the mortar anvil.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of hot water, which has been heated with fire for a little while, and hold it for the duration of an hour: and let the invalid tolerate its biting and burning, for he will find the biting to be like fire, until the biting subsides.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with the instrument, and wash away warm water from the beginning to the end along with sweet water: then let it be three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place butter on top of it, until the blackening of burning is removed: and let it be for several days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For it is the ultimate in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments, until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	But if the pain extends to the hip or leg, make a poultice for it in that which contains water, just as you did at the beginning evenly.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of warm water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkaline and unextinguished calcis, one part of each: grind them both, and put them in a new pot, whose lower part is perforated with a small hole, according to the quantity that enters into the radius; and put another glazed pot under the bottom of the first pot: and pour over the alkaline and calcis with sweet water, so that it submerges each by a finger's breadth: after which you compress them with your hand in good compression: and let the pot be, until the sharp water descends into the lower part of the glazed pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather up all that water and pour it over the other calcis: and let it be, until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be very strong and sharp, which is administered in many operations of medicine, and in the cauterizing of other limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it brings about the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from medicines are made those with which the anus is cauterized, and also like thermises, and honey of anacardium, and lime with soap, so that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen indeed reported, telling the cure of some ancient man, by which he was cured of the pain in the anus and sciatic vein: and magnified it to be very great.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that the patient does not need another treatment and that he was cured from just one remedy, until he brought it back, because perhaps himself had gone into the bath carried and had come out already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is to be taken from a green saffron: and if the green one is not found, let a dry one be taken, fresh: and let it be ground much with a little fat, and put it on the spot where there is pain, or knee, or in the hip: and bind it up, and leave it for a period of three hours, or for as long as the sick person feels relief from burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore his body becomes humid, put him on a seat.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain subsides and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that it is not fitting for anyone to use a cautery with these medicines, unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said that goat dung, when applied to a person being cauterized with it for the sciatic vein, helps him: and makes a cauterization in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let wool be taken and soaked in old oil, and let it be put on the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, and is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and burn it over the fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it on top of the wool and let it go until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat that.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	And do not stop doing that until the sense reaches through the application all the way to the knee, and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called Vaccinium.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the Cauterization of Back Pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes it happens that pain occurs in the back due to many causes, or by chance, or by a blow, or excessive evacuation, and similar things, through the infusion of cold and wet matter: and cauterization indeed does not fall, unless in this single species which is made from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary after the evacuation of the patient with pills that are fetid and similar to them, so that they be placed on the back where there is pain, three lines according to the breadth of the patient's body, after which signs are marked with encaustic in each line five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity that comes from the tolerance of the patient by his virtue: and let the cauterization be done with a cauterizing point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize three times or four with a cauterizing point of the middle claw, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in cases of Gibbous Inflammation.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness often happens to small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its inception is that it happens to boys as a constriction in breathing at elevation and motion; and you will find it in the last vertebrae of the back and knots of theirs, which has already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you see this and wish to do it, then cauterize him with a cauterizing point that is a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And take the cauterizing point over all parts of the vertebra equally: and if you wish, cauterize around the vertebra with a puncturing point two or three lines: and let them be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place until it heals with what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, lest you apply a cauterizing point to the gibbosity which occurs in a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in Gout and pains of joints.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of joints are from cold humidities that flow to any part of the body, and when they occur in the feet, according to the custom of physicians it is proper to call that Gout.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore podagra is cured due to cold causes with modes of cure, and pains are not removed, then a cauterization removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is, that he cauterizes him after purging around the joint of the feet with many cauteries; and let the cauter be Olive.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose this is the form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you wish to prick on the surface of the foot, then do so with a cauter.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	But if the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and often that happens, then cauterize him over all the knee with three cauteries, or four from every part, with the same cauter of Clavus.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	But if you need more of this cauter, then cauterize him.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not immerse your hand with the cauter, rather it should be about as thick as the thickness of skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	But if the pains ascend to the knees and back: then apply what we said earlier from the cauter, in its own chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	What if the pains are only in the hands: then prick around the wrists, as two lines turn back.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	But if there remains from the pains in the fingers: then prick them, over every joint pricking and on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	But if the pains ascend after days to the hips or shoulders: then cauterize both from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not purge the patient with a good regimen, nor by taking medicine.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen is done, and phlegm is purged, he will be healed with the help of God with this cauter.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	¶ Of the manner of cauterizing in Ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin and the intestine or bladder descends to the testicle, and it is that which begins to be near: then it is necessary for you to advise the patient to stop eating on his day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And it uses something gentle, whereby dung will descend from its stomach.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then sit him between your hands on his back: and bid him to hold his breath until he goes out, or appears to be passing stool, or intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then lead him with your fingers, and mark with an encaustum beneath the rupture above the pubic bone, with a sign whose extremity is similar to the middle of a circle above the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then use an iron cautery, which has this shape, until it comes white and sheds sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then lead the intestine or intestine back to its natural curve.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the attendant place his hand on the spot to prevent the intestine from coming out: and you have already opened up between the patient's legs, and placed a poultice underneath him, and another servant above his legs, and another above his chest who is holding hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery on top of it with your hand steady upright alongside.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold him until you reach the mouth with him: or go around him again in a different way if you are not able to reach the mouth with him at first.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe the exit of the intestine during your cautery hour, lest you burn him and cause harm to come upon the patient or even death.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not reach the mouth with the cautery, your operation does not matter.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary for the cautery of infants to be subtle, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care with the remaining ointments until he heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient lie on his back for forty days until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you place his food in proportion to the length of time required for his cure, so that it soothes his stomach: lest he excrete intestine during eating and evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to operate after forty days, then administer a well-made ligament and hold it for forty other days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him be freed from labor, and from taking food and drink, and from loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regimen, thus he is healed by a complete cure.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will say the treatment of ruptures with an incision in his chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	But when ruptures occur in the remaining part of the belly, and are just beginning, and it is desired that they not increase, then cauterize the rupture with a rounded caustic according to its size: and let what is burned be as its third from that time.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for it according to what we have said, and it will not increase.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some of the first ones have said that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular caustic, according to this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with encaustum, and a line is placed that is across the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with a caustic awl.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But first, the caustic is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On the method of cauterizing in cases of pain due to a fall or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens in some members due to a fall or blow, and pain persists for a long time, and treatment with medicines does not bring relief: then it is necessary that it be cauterized with the point caustic.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the caustic be for every part according to its size, and its softness, and weakness, and strength, and the location of the torsion, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If then he is healed by the first caustic, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then iterate over this cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Since it is customary for these pains to shift from one member to another that approaches it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore you should follow them with the cautery until the sick person is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	About the manner of cauterizing in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	But lepers are sometimes relieved by cauterization to the greatest extent.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the type of leprosy that occurs due to the putrefaction of phlegmatic and melancholic humors: when therefore you wish to cauterize it, consider it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	So if the leprosy is not responding and you have treated it as we said in the division, and it does not subside or stand still: and you fear for the patient, because corruption may spread to his entire complexion: then cauterize him on the head with five cauterizations: one in the middle of the head, marked; and a second one lower down towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two on both horns, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And with the last of your fingers and the cautery, press slightly until it makes a small impression on his mouth, and the bark breaks out: so that the exhalation of gross vapors from him may be alleviated, and cauterize also over his spleen, according to what has preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leprosy has already spread over the patient and is manifestly apparent: then it is necessary to cauterize with those cauterizations which we said in the chapter, and also cauterize on the tip of the nose, and two on each cheekbone, and two on the vertebrae of the neck, and six on the vertebrae of the back, and one large on the hips at the end of the spine and one above it, in the middle of the nape: and two on the armpits: that is to say, one on each armpit, and two on each knee, and two on each shoulder, and two on each elbow, and two on the soft parts of his chest: and cauterize him over every joint, from the joints of his fingers, hands, and feet: and cauterize also over every heel of his feet, and toe of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And beware of the nerves that are above the heel bone, lest you burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery over the hipbone, and another time over the ribcage, and again over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add to the cautery, the greater is its benefit and effectiveness.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the weak one does not find pain in a cautery, as the healthy ones do; therefore, because his body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it should be that the cauteries are of great size and smallness according to members and joints: according to what preceded from the types of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cautery with flour from a plant mixed with honey, and the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in numbness.
Caput L.	Chapter 1.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When some member is numb and is treated with medicines, oils, and poultices, but does not heal, then cauterize the numb member with cauteries, according to the magnitude of the member or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And make your cautery penetrate into the thickness of the skin a little bit.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with an ointment, until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes it is cauterized for some numbness that occurs in the hand and foot at the spine of the back where the nerves that move that member are located; and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not presume over this unless one is wise in the anatomy of members and the exit of nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in blisters.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When a blister becomes old and does not yield to anything from the arts of medicine: then cauterize over it with a deep cautery for a little bit, according to the thickness of the skin, until the whitishness is removed and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the flour of a herb, and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossa, and dove's blood, and heron's blood: each one be part of one: let these all be mixed together, and be spread over a cloth, and stick to the place, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the manner of cauterizing in Cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning to form and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circle, as if it were revolving.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But wise men have said that the cancer should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	But it doesn't seem right to me, because I fear that it will ulcers; and I have already seen this happen on a few occasions.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize around its circumference with a circle, as we said, or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the manner of cauterizing in Adubenatae.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an Adubenata and it is delayed in maturing, either because of superfluity causing it or because of the weakness of age, when there is a deficiency of blood, or because of time, and you wish to hasten its maturation; then cauterize around its circumference with small cauteries, making many punctures.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten with maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If however you wish to pierce it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, which has this shape.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Adubenata, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be from that which follows, so that the flow of pus may be eased.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the manner of cauterizing in a corrupting evil.
Caput LIIII.	Here is the translation:
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	Corrosion is not anything other than corruption in a walking member, and it corrupts it; just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	So if you see a corroding wound in a place that can tolerate cauterization with fire, then many small and great cauteries will be applied to it, according to the nature of the place where the corrosion is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all parts until you eradicate the entire corruption, and not a single thing remains of it completely.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then let it be for three days, and place over the cauterized areas sulfur that has been ground with oil, until all scabs are eradicated and all corruption.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with ointments producing flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	So if you see that after three days, healthy flesh is born, without corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not, then reapply the cautery over what remains of the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And corrosion is healed sometimes with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	Itself rises in the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, the cautery with fire is more expeditious for relief; and I have already said its division with acute medicine: therefore, take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	Of the manner of cauterizing in Claws and Warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This illness often occurs in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a thick, filtered substance that injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And there is indeed a cautery for them in two ways: one with fire and the other with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	But when it is done with fire, make the cautery cone-shaped like a vulture's beak, which should be made of iron, according to the size that contains a claw from all sides; and let it have a thin edge.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the heated instrument over the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn the hand with the cautery around the nail, until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail: and let it be for three days, until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply ointment to it with the juices of wild rue, crushed with salt: and let the dressing be on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be rooted out from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with a unguent of generated flesh, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	But if they are not converted and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in hands and feet: then administer to them a cautery with hot water: and it is, as you take a tube made of air, or iron, or from a bird's feather: and place it over the nail, or the ulcer.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small amount of hot water into the tube: hold your hand firm and turn it with compressive pressure from your own hand for a little while, so that the margin of the tube imprints itself on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail: and let the patient wait for a moment after the stinging of the hot water for one hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let it be, for the nail is rooted out with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	So do this one after another, until you come to all those that are on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they have been rooted out, with what generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	Of the manner of cauterizing in Tremors.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 56.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to someone that they tremble from cold in the nerve, or from quartan fever, or another such cause: then it is necessary for you to cauterize it four times, or five times, over the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra, and on his chest, and above his stomach.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	Shaking (tremor) ceases with olive oil cautery, and hastens recovery from cold illness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the manner of cauterizing: Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes the foul things, that is, pimples, which are produced from corrupted thick substances, are purged out of the body by Albathir.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	It is therefore necessary at first to cauterize all pimples with a subtle cautery and the wood of myrtle, whose extremity has been ignited with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of Aristolochia longa.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lentil-shaped cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.
