Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored him with medicines, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed. And this iteration of the operation on him, and the cutting open of his wound, was not necessary unless due to the debilitation of the sick person, and the scarcity of their tolerance, and my fear for him regarding death, since harm befell him at all hours from excessive purging.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	Therefore he was healed by a complete cure. And flesh hard and good grew in place of the bone, and a good arrangement took place in his body, and his strength returned. He turned back to his natural state: and there was no harm or discomfort at all in his walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone is already broken in the body: then it is necessary that you splint it, according to this method: and thus: take a ligament, and tie it at the tip of the prominent bone; and order someone to stretch it upwards; and place another ligament made from coarse wool on top of the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then tie it above the flesh that is on the bone; and stretch the end of it so as to pull the flesh down to the lower part; and you will uncover the flesh above the place which you wish to cut, in order not to injure the flesh with the cutting.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood or a board under the bone below, in the middle: because when you do that, it does not prevent the corrupt flesh from being cut.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the cutting should be above the corrupted place for a short time, so that the corruption of the bone does not occur; and its appearance does not appear to the sense, and makes another place cut in its turn.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	What if the bone is corrupted and is not prominent, but rather continues with another part; and corruption is in its middle or in a part of it: then remove all the flesh from every part.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a piece of wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then cut that from the first part where there is corruption, until the cutting continues to the other part; and let the cutting be according to length for a short time, as we said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If there is corruption in the joint, cut off the corrupted joint and saw away at the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed corruption is in the continuity of two joints, then there is no art except removal.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If corruption is in the hip of the hand or in the hip of the foot: then the matter in that case is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	However, you must investigate how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And remove it, and clean the area according to what is possible for you, and with whatever skill corrects itself to you: when it does not cause opposition from the Vein or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that scalpels and saws for cutting these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and size, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary that you prepare the suitable instrument for every kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations mean something to you according to the type of instrument you need when you have a long study with yourself.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the modes of illnesses: then indeed you will find through yourself what fits each illness from instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am strengthening you with the last number of instruments that you put examples on which you will cut, and proof by which you will test others.
Forma Serrae.	Saw form.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the other saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw is depicted, let it be well-made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper curve be a bow, its edge made of iron, and its handle made of boxwood, and let it be well-made in the shape of a pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Form of Sutures and Ligatures.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Here is the translation:
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not agree, unless the heads of the joints are rubbed with him when they are corrupted, or a large and great mouth.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The greater form of the Razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The middle form of the Razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The broad form of the Razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The Razor form with a concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The other subtle form of the Razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The other curved end form of the Razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The small, subtle form of the Razor tip.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The Razor form with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The great form also of the Razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a Rasp and its end is like a Saw: it is shown in many places for scraping bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the Razor which agrees with the perforation of what is scraped from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular and has a sharp point.
Fit ex Indi.	It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary for all things that we have said to be made of Razors, Cutters, and Saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	About the cutting off of extremities and the sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either due to an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When you have been treated for that corruption with medicines and the treatment does not help: and you see the corruption occurring in a member which does not respond to anything: then it is necessary to cut off that member up to where the corruption ends, so that the invalid may escape through it from death or from the greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign by which this happens is that the member becomes discolored and blackens until it rots: which fire has consumed or decays after turning black: until the putridity reaches to what follows the member and spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, with the incision of this sort, and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the blows of certain venomous things: as of a sea scorpion, and viper, and adder, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	Therefore, if the corruption or blow is at the end of the finger, then cut off the finger and do not give space to the corruption to spread until it reaches the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens on the hand, then cut off the hand from the wrist and do not give space to the corruption until it reaches the armpit of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it spreads into that, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption passes through and you see him around the elbow: then that person is on the point of death.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer beyond that in a cure is a quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do the same with the foot, when corruption invades a toe, then cut off that one at the first joint; and if it reaches the calf of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill left except for abandonment and leaving the sick person to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting off a limb or sawing it is to bind the ligament at the lower part which you wish to cut off and bind another ligament above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And have the assistant stretch one ligament down below: and have the assistant stretch another ligament up above upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with a spatha or broad knife, until the entire piece of flesh is uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut off, or sawed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you put a linen cloth around all parts and the saw does not touch healthy flesh: so that the patient suffers additional injury and develops a warm abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If however a flow of blood occurs inwardly while you are operating, then cauterize the place quickly: or put some absorbent powders on top that cut off the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded member with a suitable bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to a man on his foot, which is the same thing I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What is this? For it happened on his foot that a blackening occurred, resembling the burning of fire, and that corruption first affected his finger before spreading to his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man healed himself after he saw the corruption affecting his member with its madness, which he found from the pain and burning; and it happened to him at the joint, and he was cured.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred on his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me and I tried to remove the excess with him, using medicines on his hand after purifying his body; and the excess was not removed, and it began to progress to another finger: until corruption spread throughout his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called me to cut into his hand: and I did not consent to do so, hoping that the excess would be removed through my treatment; and I also feared for him death at the time of the incision on his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's strength was greater than the calamity.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Afterward, since he had lost hope in me, he returned to his land: and came back to me about it, because he was impatient, and cut off his entire hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not tell this story except as an aid to what falls under the category of this illness: and that it may be a sign by which it is shown, and according to which it should be acted upon.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the cure of sinuses and the quality of enemas with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the time for its abscess to form pus lengthens until it bursts or perforates and what is inside it comes out along with the pus, and a hollow space remains as if it were a vessel; and the skin that covers it is like a piece of cloth that has been worn thin: and it does not reach its final stage of corruption nor impress itself on bone, nerve, or ligament. It deserves to be called Sinus; and it is not called Fistula. However, if its space prolongs until corruption sets in something of these members, then it is called Fistula, or abscess.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its cure is to cut off the entire skin as it peels away; and especially when it has been worn thin and has become like a piece of cloth: and you trust that it will not adhere with the location due to its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and does not follow from this its final corruption; and if there is thickness on the skin from flesh, then cure it with an enema: and it is, to consider it at the sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor: then anoint it with an Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and zinar, parts taken in equal quantities, gathered together in a vessel: and let them be decocted over fire until the medicine becomes red-hot and arrives at a thick consistency like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need and dissolve it with water and honey, and anoint the sinus with it: and tie off its opening and let the medicine remain in it for a period of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression; make him do this daily until the sinus is cleansed and the odor removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is cleansed with water of ashes, when this medicine is not present to you: and it is, that you take the ash of wood vines or the ash from ilex woods: and pour water over it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then anoint it with it, and cleanse with it until you are confident that the sinus is now clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the patient is not able to tolerate the Egyptian medicine or the water of ashes, then cleanse him with water and honey, in which something has been mixed from crushed Indian fig.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cleanse him with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey that it cleanses and washes away: and wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this a few times and are confident that the corruption of the sinus is now removed: then cleanse him with what causes flesh to grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, that you take defuminated plaster: and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine: or cleanse him with certain medicines and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the opening of the sinus is narrow and does not admit the canula of the cleanser: then enlarge it with iron for a short time: or insert into it a linen cloth wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or Basilic ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is also large: then close its lips with a suture: and let it be as much as the cleanser can enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening from which pus flows is elevated upwards: then cut it in a lower place that is inside, so that the pus will flow downwards from there: because pus when constricted in the depth of the sinus prevents flesh from growing in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the abscess as low as you like, then try to prepare the member by preparation that will cause the pus to flow out easily, according to how it has been prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to avoid leaving anything of the pus at all in it; and take medicines that consolidate, which are placed on the sign, fitting for what you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size that there may be communication with the entire abscess.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors directly into the opening of the abscess, making the hole in the abscess a little larger.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread another cloth with soft ointments over it, according to the size of the hole; and place it over it at a distance from the opening of the abscess, so that the exit of pus from it may be eased: and do not remove the cloth completely until several days have passed by.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But the one who is over the opening of the abscess is the one you remove at every hour, so that what gathers in it from the pus may flow out; and to know whether what flows out from it is much, or little, or digested, or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this, repeatedly examine the place of the abscess itself, whether its lord feels pain in it or not, and whether there is an apostema in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment proceeds thus, and you see the material that emerges over the opening of the abscess, then you will know that the abscess is now adhering or approaching adherence: then therefore dissolve it in the morning or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound, then change another cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if after a long period a fine pus emerges from the abscess, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are people among whom the generation of flesh in their wounds is delayed, and among whom it works contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however it issues forth from the sinus after many days as a foul discharge, then you will know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the sinus is delayed and prolonged: then add to the drying of medicines that true physicians should make them humid in substance and dry in virtue, just as diaphrenic ointment when excess of addition from myrrh is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest last thing that is treated, it is to take diaphrenic ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and sprinkle over it an equal amount of old wine in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it does the same thing in this action, when you do not have diaphrenic ointment available, use honey when you cook it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloes, and frankincense: grind the whole into powder and sprinkle it over honey while it is hot.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then stretch a cloth over it and bind it over the sinus: and stretch with the honey that you cooked until it thickens: and sprinkle powder on top of it, and put it on the cloth, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with Aristolochia longa and the roots of Liliaceous Lily, and this is called Lily; and wheat flour and Centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them in simple or compound form, grind them into powder, and sift it; and sprinkle it over the honey that I told you, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	What if the sinus prolongs and does not heal with this treatment: then you will know that there is corruption deep within it; or already it makes an impression on the bones, or in other hard parts, or ligaments: then treat it with Fistula cure, according to what has been said before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the Cure of Fungus and Worn-out Nail, and Additions through the Incision of the Finger, and Section.
Caput XCI.	Here is the translation:
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritium is a boil that grows under the thumb of the hand or foot: and perhaps it grows on other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When then the matter of it is prolonged, and its cure is neglected, and a boil forms a hot boil: or it becomes corrupted, and discharges pus, until it corrupts the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts the whole thing, and perhaps the corruption reaches to the mouth, until it has a foul odor: and the tip of the finger becomes broad, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When then you treat it, as we said in the division, and your treatment does not take effect: then you must cut off with a knife all the superfluity that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For a cautery is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If however the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the growth of the nail is already pressing on the flesh to the inside, and begins to pierce it, and hurt it: then you should put a thin piece of cauterized radium under the angle of the nail that pierces the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut away the flesh with ease, and place over what remains of the flesh from medicines that burn and corrode, until the whole thing is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however corruption has already taken hold in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away that bone and remove it: for it never heals as long as the corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	What if you see corrosion and corruption spreading into the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to what was previously mentioned about its remembrance.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however there is nail attrition or percussion, and a severe pain accompanies it, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp Spatumilus section transverse from above downward.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care lest the incision reaches the flesh beneath the nail, for if you do so, you will cause severe pain to the inferior part and it will be the reason for the added flesh growing in its place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the wound with something that soothes pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	However, the added finger that grows on some people's hands is perhaps entirely fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them; and perhaps it has a nail: and some of them grow at the root of the joint or their birth is in certain knots of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, that which grows in certain knots of the finger does not move: and that which grows at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, since the one that is fleshy among them is so, its cutting is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	What is, to cut it at its root with a broad Spatumilus.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the treatment of that which grows at the joint of the root is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, refrain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	However, the one that grows on the finger at the end of the knots, then it is necessary to cut into its first flesh with a rounded incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then file off the bone with one of those files that are suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the formation that occurs on fingers individually, often occurs either from the birth of a person, that is, it grows with him, or from the consolidation of a wound, or burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	It is necessary therefore that you cut off that formation until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place licinia or cloth soaked in rose oil between them: so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate between them: or place a thin sheet of lead between them, until the location consolidates as needed.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if consolidation occurs on some fingers with the palm, then cut off that consolidation, according to what is prepared and conforms to the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On cutting out defects.
Caput XCII.	Head 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Varicose veins are those which are twisted, thickened, and full of superfluous melancholic humors that occur in many parts of the body: and most often they happen in legs, particularly in the legs of travelers and workers, and carriers.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary to administer a purgation of the body with black choleric medication several times with strong purging.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then let a bloodletting be performed on the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	However, their treatment with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are cauterized and the black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that the vein is raised and the entire thing is drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Bind the leg first with warm water a great deal until the thick, dirty blood has dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the weak leg from the upper part of the hip down to the lower part of the knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three, in a wide section.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then lift, that is, draw out the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and it is necessary for the phlebotomist to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut off the nail as far as the lower part: until a quantity of blood comes out which you see is sufficient and which the strength of the patient can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it and tell him to abstain from foods that generate black bile, and iterate the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are filled and that hurts the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the crippled leg, if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert him into the bath; or pour hot water over his leg with a sponge, until it turns red and the veins are opened up: or exercise him in strong physical activity, if there is no bath available, until the limb is warmed up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin along the direction of the vein's section by length: or at its end near the knee, or in the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the cut with a scalpel, and strip the vein of all its covering, until it becomes visible to the sense; and it is at that moment when you see it turn from red to dark brown.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it then comes out of the cut, you see it white as if it were a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert Radium underneath it, until when it is elevated and comes out of the cut; tie it with a blind ligature, gentle.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another section nearby, three finger's length away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then strip the cut from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate it with Radium as you did, and tie it with another ligature, just as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another section, or multiple sections, if needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate and incise the very last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove it to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do that until you remove it from the section above, or higher sections altogether, until when it emerges entirely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If however it does not obey you to remove and elevate: then insert a hook with a strong string doubled, and tie it, and pull it out; or insert underneath it Radium: and turn your hand around every direction until it emerges.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to lift it strongly, and an evil consequence will ensue upon the sick person from that.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when you have entirely extracted it: then place a cloth soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil, over the wound, and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	And if the vitriol is contracted, having a twisted shape and being wrapped around parts, and it is not as we said, straight: then you must cut through it on all sides of its twistiness, and the places where it wraps itself.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with a hook until you lift it all out: and beware at your cutting through it not to cut the vein or wound it: for it will be difficult for you to lift it up or draw it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of Cutting Whereby the Vitriol is Healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The Form of a Blind Knot.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curved like other knots, nor is it sharp at its end, so as not to wound the vein; and it has a thickness of flexuousness, gentle: for if it were subtle, it would cut the vein by its subtlety: nay, let its superfluous thickness be as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Vein of the Thigh.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This Vein is generated in the thighs of people on hot earth, like that of Alizeg, and of the Arabs, and on dry, hot lands with little fertility, that is, where no grass grows nor tree.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as it happens within bodies to snakes and ascaris worms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's outcome is that which happens in the leg a violent inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is cleaned.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from that place of cleaning, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	Therefore, when the end of it appears from there, then it is necessary to wrap a piece of lead over it, weighing one and two-thirds drachma keil, and bind the lead suspended from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever then something emerges from it to the outside, wrap that in lead, and bind it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	What if it is prolonged greatly, then cut off a part of it, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut off its root before it has emerged entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	Because if you cut it, it contracts and enters the flesh, and causes an abscess, corruption in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to handle it gently and draw it out gradually, until it emerges from its entirety, and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this vein some people emerge in a length of five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has reached me, because it emerged from a man twenty palms long.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it happens to you during your medication hour: then insert the tip into its opening, and pierce it with a long opening, together with the body, until everything that is in it is evacuated from the material: and administer putrefaction of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the cure by treating abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or on the foot itself: and it has many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore treat it as we said in division, and with what has been previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	About the cutting of worms born under the skin, and it is called a Boar's sickness.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This sickness is called "Boar's sickness" in a certain land among us because it frequently occurs in oxen and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it moves throughout the body, ascending and descending, and is shown to the sense at every step of its movement from member to member, until it breaks wherever it breaks in the skin, and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and serpents, namely, lice and ascarids, occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And fear is to be had from its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it goes into the body and rises to the head and reaches a place, then perhaps it opens up there and emerges, and destroys an eye: and that happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it and draw it out, then that does not happen except at every step of its movement and appearance to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore you must tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong binding constraint.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and draw it out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	What if it burrows into the flesh and you don't find it: then place a caustic on top of the spot with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than that which is to be feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts an eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then tie below it the eyebrow with a good tightening.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and draw it out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the patient uses the cleansing of his body with medicines dissolving bad, putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that produce putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the Lancing above Disease Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called Nakir in our land; and it is a pain that occurs in certain members, then it is changed from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I indeed have seen him myself, according to what I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I had stayed for one hour, I saw a swelling move with the pulse, just like a worm moves, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than it can be, so that it is like living silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain then departed from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for one hour and it ran to another part of the body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving throughout her entire body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed therefore at the rapidity of its changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I indeed had not seen this disease with my own eyes in such a way before that time.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However I have seen many who found pain changing from member to member; and I did not see it with my own eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it is anything except that the woman was one of those who are from dry and discovered veins of the body; therefore it becomes apparent to my senses that this swelling is being moved.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they not appear according to this reason in those who are delicieux and have moist bodies and hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	So when you want to treat it and the patient feels that pain, then if it appears to your eye as we said, then tie above it quickly, and beneath it swiftly: and cut above it until the constricted swelling goes out: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then cure it by excision of the body, and with that which drives out swellings, and bind them up with fetid pills, and pills of serapeum, and similar ones.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Of the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are differentiated according to their own kinds and according to the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	And their variety is this: because there are some that have large points and small ones: and hollow-tipped and pointed.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them there are those with tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them there are those with stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those however that fall according to the members, is in two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the members are from the main concave members, such as the brain, and the heart, and liver, and lung, and kidney, and intestines, and bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls on one of these members and apparent signs of death appear to you which I will tell you next, then it is necessary that you extract the arrow from there, for death follows him who has it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it and cure the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When a dart falls into the brain and pierces the skull, and emerges above the brain, it causes: convulsions, scotoma, vertigo, redness in the eyes, inflation, redness of the tongue, spasm, and a mixture of intellect, and vomiting with bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will flow out from the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And a white discharge like pus flows out from the wound site.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And a fluid similar to serum of meat exits from it.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	So if these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment and remove the dart if it does not emerge.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the dart when it falls into the heart are that it is near the left breast, and it feels as if it were fixed in hard substance, not in empty space.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the dart's movement is similar to the movement of a pulse: and dark blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And then follows numbness in the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death is undoubtedly impending.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the dart when it wounds the lung is the emission of frothy blood from the wound: and the vessels that follow the neck become inflamed, and their color changes to that of a sick person.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And it exhales a great and deep breath: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	Which if the dart falls into the membrane that is in the chest: then it is near the small ribs; and a great gasping occurs with intense pain, with a sigh: and all the limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the dart falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from food will emerge from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and is stuck there: something foul-smelling exits from the wound, or pus, or intestine that is already torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore, there is no hope for its cure, nor for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	For if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine flows out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is more intense on the afflicted person: then you will know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	However, other parts of the body, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and shoulder blade, and rib, and loin, and leg, and similar ones are treated with poultices from the limbs, according to many dispositions: when the arrow does not find an artery or nerve: and the arrow is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you what I have seen about these arrows, so that you may infer from it about your own cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	For it is this: a man had an arrow fall into the root of his nose, at the base of his tearful eye.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from him on the other side, under his ear fat: and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not succeed in extracting more than a small part of it, with which it was stuck in its wood: and the arrow was great among the arrows of Turkish bows, with a soft iron tip, without an ear.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore, the Jew was healed, and no evil happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And the arrow was Arab, and it is one that has an ear.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I secured it above it between two guides: and already it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I have skillfully handled her until I extracted it from her: and a Christian has been healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die because of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed and nothing had changed in his condition, I observed the arrow; and I examined it, and extracted it; and he was healed, and no further harm came to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man on whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound was consolidated over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years had passed, the arrowhead emerged at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman on whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound was consolidated over it, and the arrowhead remained inside her: and nothing changed in her condition, and the woman did not find any harm from any of her natural bodily functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man on whom an arrow had fallen on his face: and the wound was consolidated, and remained without finding much pain; and similar things were seen.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the King's princes, which had fallen into his nose and was already leaning towards the right side; and the arrowhead was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called therefore to treat him after the arrow shot, until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found then a wound of the arrow very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I then probed it with a fine probe and did not feel it; and he himself was finding a puncture and pain under his ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore supposed that that puncture was from the tip of the arrowhead.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore applied a poultice to the place with a poultice that had attracting and digestive power, having confidence in myself that the area would suppurate and that I would see a sign of the arrowhead appearing, so that I could cut above it: and no accident occurred at the place indicating that the arrowhead was located there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore I applied the poultice to him for many days and it did not happen that anything untoward occurred, and the wound was consolidated in the meantime: and he remained lame from the extraction of his space of days until he felt a dart one day inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I applied a sharp, corroding medicine to that wound for many days until it opened up: and when I probed him, and felt the slender extremity of the arrow which was stuck in wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until the extremity of the arrow appeared visibly to us: and it passed by me along with him for a period of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been widened and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move it, but it did not obey my exit: then I did not cease to whittle away at it and invent methods on top of it with various contrivances, until one day I began to extract it with well-made forceps, according to the shape they would take at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that the nasal cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it and the wound was consolidated and the patient recovered with complete and entire health: nor did anything at all harm him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: so that you may place it as a rule and signification over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and their distinctions cannot be comprehended by narrative: nor does that book comprehend it, and a wise craftsman compares little with much: and he also finds what is present over what is absent: and he discovers a new operation and a new instrument in the descent of external matters of this art when accidents occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I therefore say that arrows do not exit from the limbs on which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or through the opposite part of the other side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits where it entered is either an arrow proceeding to a fleshy place and being drawn out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	For if it does not obey the exit at the time when it falls: then one must let it be for some days, until the flesh that is around it has putrefied: and its attraction and exit will be eased.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in bone and does not obey you to exit, then let it be for some days: and repeat the process of attraction and motion every day, until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	For if it does not obey you to exit after days, then one must pierce the surrounding flesh of the arrow in the bone from every part with a fine file, until the arrowhead is enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull and has already penetrated one ventricle of the brain, and certain symptoms of those things I mentioned appear: then abstain from attracting the arrow and let it be until its position becomes stable after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the siphac, then death will not be prolonged to him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of a bone only, and does not penetrate to the siphac; and the patient remains infirm for some days, and nothing from those things happens to him: then one should exercise ingenuity in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very strongly and does not obey you to the attraction: then administer a file to the surrounding area of the arrow, as I narrated to you; then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however an arrow has already been lodged in the body and is hidden from sight, and is concealed from sense perception: then search for it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If however you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for drawing it out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If however you cannot reach it above, due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow deep within, and there is no bone, nerve, or vein: then find a way to reach it until the wound is enlarged and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	And if there are ears that it holds to, then free the fixed flesh from all sides, in every way you can, and with arts, if it cannot be freed by going over the edge of the ear, and by bending them until it goes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow, wherever it may be, then use a twisting motion with your hand, along with forceps, to all parts, until you make it come out: and with utmost subtlety, so that the arrow does not break and the extraction becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	And if you cannot remove it from one hour to another, then leave it for a few days, until what is around it begins to decay.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then reiterate it: the swelling will indeed be alleviated. If however blood flux makes contrary to you, then administer what we said in its own chapter: and preserve your strength from cutting a vein, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And apply skill in every way that it is possible for you to extract the arrow: and let it be with ease, and calmness, or slowness, and firmness, just as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that when you pull out the arrow, the patient be made weak according to the shape, according to which he was at the time of the arrow's impact.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if it's not possible for you, then do what is possible for you from the shapes.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	However, the arrow that emerges from the opposite part of the other [side], either already proceeds something to the exterior or causes a swelling at the end of the Arrow by feeling on the superior part of the nearby skin, and you see it protruding: therefore, cut above it, and let the incision be according to the quantity that the forceps can take in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for it becomes easy to come out by itself.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the Arrow impresses itself on the bone and enlarges its own depth: then draw it out.
