Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then reiterate the procedure until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	What if the wood of the Arrow is stuck in it, then push it with that [wood].
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the wood has fallen and you wish to administer a push: then introduce a concave instrument into it, so that it enters its concavity into the tail of the Arrow: then push it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the Arrow is concave, then push it with the instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The Arrow is eased by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	What if the Arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to remove all the flesh where the venom is, if that is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with what is fitting for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	What if the Arrow falls in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and it is close to what you touch with your hand, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware of cutting into a vein, or nerve, and draw it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then treat a wound, if you see one, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the shape of forceps by which arrows are pulled out.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let their extremities be like the beak of a bird, made as if from iron; when they take hold above an arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many kinds of them are made, great, small, and middle-sized, according to the size, magnitude, and narrowness of the arrow, and the size, width, and constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of a spoon is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the shape of an obtuse impeller.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is like the blunt end of a radius, so that it may be inserted into an arrow and pushed along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The blunt end of the concave impeller is concave like a bird's feather: so that the entrance of the arrow may be inserted into it and pushed forward with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On bloodletting of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are accustomed to be bloodletted in the body are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of which sixteen are in the head: two pulse-beating veins that are behind the ears and are called Herbae; and two arteries that appear in both temporal regions; and two veins that are in both tear ducts of both eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidigie veins that are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are called Algecherich veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are tapped for bloodletting on arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it is located on the lateral side of the shoulder; and the people call it the "head" vein.
Et Fusca.	And the Axillary.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Median vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilic and a branch of the Cephalic: and the people call it the "body" vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic, and it is located on the lateral side of the arm: and it is also called the Tertian.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the people call it the "abdominal" vein.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Armstring vein, and it is located above the elbow; and it is that which is tapped for bloodletting, and it is the one that is visible above the wrist, with a clear appearance.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Cedrella: and it is a vein that is located between the Annular and Median: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the leg and foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is located under the curvature of the toe on the lateral side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second one is the Saphena: and its location is at the heel, from the lateral side of the foot.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Nerve: and its location is at the heel, from the lateral side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in another leg there are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Of Bloodletting from Two Veins after the Ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bloodletting from two veins that are after the ears is beneficial for old catarrhs, and hemicrania, and sahafa, and bad old head sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting it is according to what I narrate.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, as I said, to shave the head of the sick person: and to rub his occiput with a rough cloth in the place of the two veins with good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient tightens his neck with a bandage until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And those places are located after the ears, on two depressed parts of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore search for them with your finger and where you feel a pulse beneath your finger, mark it with an encaustic.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the bloodletting knife, which is called the "Incidens".
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the vein into the flesh until the bloodletting reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and the skin to the top, and cut the vein with a cutting wound that cuts into the skin.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the width of two joined fingers, or roughly that; and make as much blood flow out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it with lint, and let it go until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now precedes the incision of those veins and their cauterization, which was discussed at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	§ On bloodletting from two arteries at a time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The benefit of bloodletting from the two arteries located in both temporal regions is for an old headache; and a bad cough; and constant tearing of the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bleeding them is as I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient tightens his neck greatly until two veins appear in a manifestly visible way; and show their pulse under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark it with an encaustic.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin above the vein to the top with your finger as a guide, and introduce the bloodletting knife beneath, and lift the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did in the other two veins; and make the blood flow out according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the constriction of the patient, and place your finger on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	After that, place a compress and poultice on it, and bind it tightly above with strong constriction; and let it be until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And already a reminder of those things, and the cutting and extraction of them is presented at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of bloodletting from the forehead vein after cephalic bloodletting.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The remedy for bloodletting from the forehead vein is after cephalic bloodletting, for old facial ailments: and for headache, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of its bloodletting is, according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient should constrict his neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose form is this.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point that is on top of the Fossorium head on top of the vein, and strike it gently with a plectrum or some other instrument in its way; and let the blood flow as much as you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then loosen the perforation of the patient, and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad bloodletting.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary for the bloodletting to be sharp at its extremity, like the other bloodlettings, but rather it should be broad.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And perform the bloodletting through perforation, because it is nearby; and perhaps the bloodletting may be broken when it is subtle.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of bloodletting from the veins in both tear ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The remedy for the two veins that are in both tear ducts of two eyes is for an eye with a scab and redness: and swelling in the eye, and facial ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of bleeding for those is, that a sick person binds his neck with a thread.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then make incisions on them; and you be standing above his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the bleeding be done across in a little bit of length, with a small, broad instrument, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the bleeding is at the end of a thin extremity, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make flow from the blood as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a cloth on them, and bind them one night, and release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On the Bleeding of Veins of the Nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are for bleeding that is suitable for acute fever and violent headache, and also for facial afflictions, such as hemicrania and redness that occurs on the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of bleeding for that is, that a sick person binds his neck with a thread.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand and take a thin, long bleeding instrument; and place it in the middle of the hare's joint itself, between that which separates the nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary for you to keep your hand with the bleeding instrument a little bit; and make flow from the blood as much as you need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind them one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On the Bleeding of Veins of the Gullet.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The benefit of the two bleedings of the Gullet is for constriction of panting, and onset of leprosy, and melancholic afflictions, and impetigo, and bad ulcers, and corroding sores, that is, herpes-like.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of bloodletting is that the patient lies under both [bandages] on his neck with a strap; and the artist stands over the head of the patient, and the patient sits on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then bloodletting is performed on the vein for the length of a broad bloodletting.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then take out a measured amount of blood, or as much as necessity requires in the case you are treating.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same thing to another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the strap and bind both veins together with a moderate tightness, so that the patient is not overheated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healing.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	A Treatise on Bloodletting of Veins by Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are the benefit of bloodletting because they contribute to a headache at the mouth and corruption of the gums; and bad wounds; and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, even those that are on the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of bloodletting is that you make the patient sit before you; and bind his neck with a strap.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn his lip back and look at the two veins: one is on the right side of his lip, and the second is on the left side of it; and the demonstration of each is by the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because around those are small, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut both with a single incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if you are in doubt about it and do not know which one is which: then direct your attention to the larger and more prominent of the two.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do the same thing to the two veins that are on the upper lip: and indeed a great deal of habit is with him: and cut the two veins that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On bloodletting from the vein under the tongue after cephalic bloodletting.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The benefits of bloodletting from the two veins that are under the tongue: it is because cephalic bloodletting is for choking fits that occur in the throat, and troubles of the uvula, and troubles of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bloodletting them is, that you cause the patient to sit between your hands before the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under his tongue from one side a vein, and from the other side another vein: and the color of both will decline to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, bleed both of them; and take care not to put your last finger on bleeding them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under these are arteries, and perhaps a flow of blood may occur from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are bled on the elbow are those in which it is a custom for everyone to have bloodletting.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their bloodletting is done according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by piercing with a myrtle-leafed lancet; or by oiling to subtlety decline; or by cutting with a knife-cultellary, and that is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Such is Alnesil, which is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there are broad and subtle species according to the breadth and constriction of the veins. The form of bloodletting with a myrtle leaf is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening up concave, full, proceeding, apparent, thick veins, and those which contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this bloodletting is of lesser breadth and more subtle at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bloodletting of thin veins which contain citrus-colored blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Here is the translation:
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilica, which is one of the three veins, is a source of benefit for bloodletting.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the illnesses that are under the throat and neck, following the chest and belly; and it suits the bloodletter to cut into this vein, so he may beware of it and be on guard against fear, for beneath it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he erred and added to the incision of bloodletting, he will cut into that artery, and a flow of blood will occur.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary for the phlebotomist not to cut this vein with a puncturing instrument; rather, let him cut it with an Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If this basilica does not appear with a clear manifestation, then it is necessary to abandon it and seek another one, or find a branch of it; or if there is no alternative, use the tendon of the arm as a substitute.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For this one is clear and can be cut with a phlebotomy instrument called Alnesil, just as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform bloodletting on this very one, then it is necessary before tightening the arm, that you touch the place until you know the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with encaustic, afterwards the arm, and cut the vein with a concave section using the phlebotomy instrument called Alnesil, just as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware that the blow does not fall through the space to the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that as you tie the bandage, there is swelling in the place you marked with encaustic, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery; therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	What if you see blood flowing during the phlebotomy, like a child's urine, and it is fine and red: then you will know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore hasten and place your finger on top of the space for a long time, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then bind the arm and let it go: and let the sick person beware of its motion: and be on guard against its fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days, until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood is not cut off and prevails over you, and medicine is not present to you at that moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities contract and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of flaxen cord and tie it; take one half of it and bind it over the place where the vein is to be constricted, with a ligature and small pills until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then cure it with the one whose remembrance preceded from the place of powder-removing blood flow; and its blood cutting off is not difficult in many dispositions, due to the small wound location and the possibility of a ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	A treatise on bleeding the Black Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The Black Vein is helpful for phlebotomy, because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: therefore, since it is composed of a branch of the Basilic vein and a branch of the Cephalic vein, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is suitable for the one performing phlebotomy to choose this vein, so that it will be over the fear of bleeding from it, for beneath it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore the phlebotomist adds to the puncture and finds a nerve, it happens that there is numbness, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps does not heal at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in certain people, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then you must put your phlebotomy in such a way that you will phlebotomize the section with Alnesil, and avoid hitting the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If a vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Here is the translation:
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The veins of phlebotomy in the cephalic region are helpful, because they attract blood from the head and bring relief to eye afflictions.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein, if you wish, to make an incision with a sesame oil phlebotome or a myrtle oil phlebotome: because it is the most salubrious of all veins, since there is no artery underneath nor nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, it is suitable for you at the time of phlebotomy to remove the head of the phlebotome just up to the wrist and look for a softer spot; and it will not harm him if he does not find it with the first blow, but rather repeat the process several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, perhaps it will suppurate in some people if it is not phlebotomized at the first blow, but that swelling will do no harm to him.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the utility of Phlebotomy and precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality however of Phlebotomy and its accidents from which you should reflect on how to correct them.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First therefore of that which you should know is this: that Phlebotomy is not administered except for the conservation of health, and the perseverance of its continuity, and caution against the approach of afflictions.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that Phlebotomy may be done in one of the three veins on the shoulder, namely, the Cephalic, and the Black, and the Royal.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that Phlebotomy should be done at the beginning of spring after fasting, in March and autumn after eating, when signs of replenishment appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And that Phlebotomy should be done on the first or third day, after three hours have passed since sunrise.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But Phlebotomy which is administered for illnesses does not have a fixed hour; but when the occasion and necessity require it, whether by night or day, at any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not fitting that children be bled until they come of age at fourteen years.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be bled, except from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should old men who have already passed sixty years be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wants to be bled for whatever reason: it is necessary that he cleanse his bowels beforehand with a gentle enema, if much feces has been retained in them: so that the veins may not attract at the time of bleeding the superfluous putrid things from the bowels that are harmful to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient be bled who is drunk with excessive eating or drinking, nor one who is vomiting from excess, nor one who has just recovered from drunkenness, until that state passes away from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor should an invalid with dropsy be bled.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bloodletting should be avoided again after a colic attack, and vomiting, and diarrhea, and frequent coitus, and labor, and exercise, and wakefulness, and fasting, and all that dissipates the vital force from bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of humors beforehand, whether the blood is thickened with foods and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible to do so.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then enter the bath, unless something prevents it; or engage in some exercise, in order that the blood may be refined.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And put his bloodletting in the chest, on the third day, as we said: and strive to purge out his chest that day from all bad animal affections, such as anxiety, anger, fear: and from all bodily afflictions, such as labor, pain, excesses, and those similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And make the remedies of his own kind present with which custom has accustomed people to use through aromaticity, and scenting, and dancing, and similar things in proportion to the possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the phlebotomator should sit on a cushion which is higher than the one used for phlebotomy. Afterwards, he should take out his own arm and rub it with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he should tie a ligament with a belt, and wrap it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be moderate, for when it is unequal, or there is too much constriction, then it hinders the flow of blood; or if it is loose, then also it hinders the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, it is necessary for the one to be bled to rub his hands together evenly until the veins are inflated and become apparent to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomator should wipe the wound with a little old oil, properly.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his index finger of the left hand on top of the vein at the spot where he wants to make the incision, slightly so that the vein does not flee and a blow can be struck.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For just as the string flees from the phlebotomist during surgery, so too do the veins flee when one places the phlebotomy instrument on them. And there are some that are full of wind: and when you place the phlebotomy instrument on it, it contracts beneath the phlebotomist, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and the phlebotomy does not open up the vein; and if it does open up, it is constricted. Therefore it is necessary for the phlebotomist to be firm and attentive in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should remove the phlebotomy instrument.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If the vein opens up on one side, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then do the same thing on the other side a little bit away or above it with haste: unless the spot becomes inflamed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	That if it becomes inflamed or swells up with disease, then let him rest for a day or two: and do not bind the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it will attract a warm abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor should he enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he will repeat venesection, if desired.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	But if the aperture is small, or the blood flows thinly, and you fear that not enough blood will come out: then repeat venesection in the same opening, following its natural direction, and add a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this quickly, before the area becomes inflamed, for an inflamed area is a common occurrence in many people during a minor procedure.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see it already inflamed, then do not repeat the procedure at all on it, for nothing excuses itself with you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something from oil and dung over it, because it will ease the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better here than oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer oil and dung in all your venesections, where you make incisions to stop the flow of blood; and it is called tyriaca by Alfarach, and sagzenea when one of them is placed over the area.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood becomes thinner and is dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	For if a great abscess occurs at the site of the venesection, which often happens, especially to those who are not accustomed to it except for this occasion, or if the opening of the vein is small; then hurry and place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed slightly, over the area, and bind it for one hour: because it will dissolve.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary to do this after the blood has stopped flowing from that very vein, when its flow is complete, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	And if something remains at the site after a few days, whether it is black or greenish in color, it does not harm; and if you wish, place something over it from aloes, or myrrh solvents, or something from the sap of calament, that is, like menthe.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times indeed accidents and swellings occur at bloodletting in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So put your hand on it, then if you find softness under your pressure on it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	So beware, so as to put something on it from what we said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a poultice for it with that which has astringency, so that the place may be hardened.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you withdraw blood from every man according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears by the color victorious over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it go out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it go until it becomes fine; and similarly if it is sharp, then let its sharpness be taken away.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting once, that phlebotomy be increased on the vein, and let the phlebotomist be broad-shouldered; and in one who is weak, let it be the opposite of this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he draw it out in sections and that the opening be narrow; and better is what is administered in vein phlebotomy, that there be a transverse incision, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of bloodletting is safe from the flow of blood and from cutting into the nerve; and it is more praiseworthy and healthier than bloodletting by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for one who is accustomed to syncopes coming on during bloodletting, it is necessary that he eats a moderate amount of bread soaked in grape juice water before the bloodletting; or safflower if he is heated: and let him withdraw from him from the blood in three sections or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is chilled, then it should take a bread infused with honey syrup, or with a sweetened honey syrup flavored with spices, or with an aromatic and fragrant syrup before bloodletting.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncope occurs during bloodletting and is due to the excessive exit of blood: then it is necessary that he should drink a broth of meat, and a subtle fragrant syrup: and make use of aromatic substances with aloes, and anoint his chest with them: and make use of the other things we mentioned in the division of syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	However, he who wants to release his arm and shed his blood a second time: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is due to abundant evacuation and whose strength is weak, to let out the blood gradually by the amount of their strength over several days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wants to release his arm and shed his blood a second time, and his body is strong: then let him do it after seven hours or nine from his first bloodletting.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wants to attract blood from his body to the opposite side to which it is declining: it is necessary that he do so on the second day or third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body is a great deal of blood already warmed up, sharpened, and causing fever: it is necessary that the blood exit from him on one side, and a large quantity be drawn out: and the opening be widened until syncope occurs: after which you should have preserved all conditions of phlebotomy: and place your hand on his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death may not occur instead of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens that this occurs when the phlebotomist is ignorant and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you want to release the arm and shed blood a second time, when already the orifice of the vein is closed and the exit of blood becomes difficult, that you should press upon it with forcefulness and cause it to be quickly bent or stretched.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a very bad thing, I mean let it go until it is bled second.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with sharp bleeding whatever has been clotted from blood in the wound opening, and place something of dissolved salt on top of it in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put something from Tyrian pitch or saffron on top of it, and place a gentle compression on it until the blood goes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If the vein is already inflamed, then let it be, and do not bind it, until the inflammation subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	What if necessity requires to let out blood again, and there is no excuse, then either bleed above that place or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	However, the veins of the arm are bled at the places known as Fusca and Basilia, when those cannot be found, and they are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of this bleeding is that the patient should put his hand into hot water until it turns red and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then a ligature should be tied above it with a moderate degree of constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then bleed secondarily by transverse punctures gradually, not widthwise nor lengthwise: and let the aperture be wide, and let your bleeding be such that it flows over the juncture of the hand a little bit.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	What if the flow of blood is hindered? Then repeat the motion with your hand in hot water, and let the blood run out into the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in summer days, then excuse yourself from repeating the hand motion in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed the flow of blood is put to a great extent in hot water during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the bleeding of this vein is more beneficial to all veins, because it is not under a pulsating vein nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Venesection is the right hand of Saluta's salvation, it relieves diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of venesection is that you bind with a ligament or your own hand the vein after you have inserted it into warm water until it swells and becomes very sensitive to the touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then cut the vein across.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, that will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And take care, lest your hand be stained with the venesection.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the naked nerves of the fingers exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then put your hand into warm water and let the blood flow freely in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not put it into warm water, the blood will congeal in the wound of the vein and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted the necessary amount of blood, then place oil and salt over the vein so that it does not congeal quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, it is necessary to do this with every tightened branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The remedy for the venesection is from the left hand, because it relieves spleen diseases; and similarly do this with his venesection as you did with the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The remedy for the phlebotomy of the saphena is for diseases that are in the lower part of the body, such as womanly complaints, retention of menses, and weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and legs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that the patient puts his foot into warm water and makes a friction on it until the veins swell; and bind above the joint of the foot with a strap.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the location of the veins is at the heel, appearing towards the thumb, and they branch out from there into multiple branches on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Let blood from it on a larger branch of his, or at the heel in its gathering, for it is better and more wholesome.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you let blood from it on the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are under it above the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your incision so that you may let blood from it sideways, as if you were willing to cut it: and the incisor is Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the flow of blood is hindered, then go down to his foot in hot water: and let the blood run out into it, until it is purged.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	That if the physician makes a mistake in the first attempt, then he should go back with the lancet to a higher place a little bit, for the spot is safe, and you are not afraid of evil consequences when you beware of the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the vein on the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the Sciatic veins, as we said, is at the heel from the left side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the benefit of his bleeding is to relieve the pain in the ankle when it occurs due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of his bleeding is that the patient should enter the bath and hasten; and bind his leg on the side of the ankle up to the heel by four fingers with a thin, long string: for it appears only because of this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then let blood from it according to whatever nature is possible for you, either by transversing or by making an incision or a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For that place is more wholesome, and it is very hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	But if you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the sense: then let blood from some branch of it, and that is the one which appears on the back of the foot and towards the ear; and beware of the nerves, and make the blood flow out in a quantity as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and place the skin over the spot of bloodletting, and tighten the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it heals quickly indeed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of Pneumothorax, and its quality.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Pneumothoraces occur from horns, and from air, and from vinegar.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Pneumothorax indeed occurs in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and bloodletting: and the other is pneumothorax without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this Pneumothorax which is without scarification, is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventoses that are administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	One of which is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head; and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and ventoses Alhagdahim, and they are two plates of the neck from both sides simultaneously; and ventoses of the mind, and it is under the jawbone in the lower part of the mouth; and ventoses of the two spatula-like places; and ventoses of Alachosos above the end of the tail; and ventoses of the two forearms, and they are in the middle of the two arms; and ventoses of the two hind legs; and ventoses of the two scapular areas.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed, Pneumothorax does not extract blood from you from small scattered veins in the flesh, and because of that, it does not fall into power, just as is the case with bloodletting.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor should pneumothorax be administered, whether with fire or without fire, in any disease that arises from excess, until the entire body has been purged.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	But if necessity demands pneumothorax due to illness or habit, we administer it at every hour at the beginning of the month, its end, and its middle, and whenever it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	What is this? Because there are people who, when blood multiplies within him until he needs its extraction by lancing, find a swelling in their head and then swoon.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them are those who find fullness and redness on their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them are those who find itching on their face and forehead, and darkness and dimness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them are those who scratch the place of their lancing.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose laughter increases.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And among them are those who find the taste of blood in their mouth: or their tongue will break out and spit up blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose sleep increases.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among them is one who sees blood and redness, and killed ones, and wounds, and things similar to those in their sleep.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see something of these things, and especially if it occurs on the 15th day: then we prescribe lancing to be done two hours or three after sunset.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The relief of lancing the head is: because it brings about heaviness on the head, and what is poured out to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it should be done after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is the lancing in place of the cephalic bloodletting.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed to use it on someone who has a cold complexion or one who has a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of that, one should not use this on the elderly or someone whose head is troubled by cold afflictions.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But whoever becomes accustomed to it, forgetfulness is generated in him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of that, one should instruct the lancer to put down his hand with the lancet a little while after to the lower parts, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is a place for dark bloodletting and basilic vein bloodletting. It is useful for relieving breathing difficulties and chest constriction, facilitating the use of instruments, and curing coughs and replenishing.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary for the Ventosatio Alkehel to be pushed slightly forward, because if it is placed below, it produces weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The Ventosatio alhagdahim relieves pains and accidents in the head, and also the eyes, and headaches, and perforations, and pain in the roots of teeth; and it is a place for basilic vein bloodletting.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to warn the Ventosator not to press his hand with scarification so that he does not hit an artery and a flow of blood occurs.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The Ventosatio under the jaw relieves apoplexy in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar troubles from diseases that are in the mouth; and it is a place for bloodletting alieherich which are in both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The Ventosatio of spatulas relieves alchafacham, which is caused by relaxation and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The Ventosatio of the inner parts of two furnaces relieves the benefit of bloodletting from three veins, namely the basilic, cephalic, and femoral: because it attracts blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh; and those small veins attract blood from other larger veins until the attraction reaches the three said veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary to warn the Ventosator not to proceed too much in scarification, because the location is laid bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The Ventosa which is applied above the alcausos relieves hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary to warn the Ventosator that the Ventosa should be large and made of air: because the location needs strong suction, and perhaps the fine Ventosae may break: and there should be great scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Wind veins of the legs decrease by manifest diminution; for they draw blood from the whole body and transfer old pains to the kidneys, bladder, and matrix: they provoke menstruation and transfer inflammation and swelling. And they take the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and the Alkhoroubian vein.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body greatly, and cause syncope to occur in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the benefit of the Alkhoroubian vein is similar to the benefit of the two veins of the legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the wind veins is that you place the wind vein in the first empty space, and draw out with a tempered suction: and do not prolong the position of the wind veins, but put them quickly and remove them quickly, so that the humors come to the spot with equal arrival: and do not stop repeating it and continuing, until you see the spot already reddened and inflamed, and appears as a redness of blood: then indeed scarify, and iterate suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the dispositions of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For those among humans who have thin flesh, rare pores, it is necessary that you scarify him once only, not more: lest the place becomes ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the wind vein operator to amplify the scarification and deepen it slightly: and temper the suction in ease, swiftness, and sweetness.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	What if there is coagulation in the blood, then it is necessary that you scarify him twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first instance, indeed, the way is opened for subtletization of the blood and its moistening: and in the second instance, indeed, a thorough and meticulous extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is very foul, then a third scarification should be performed: so that the outcome may be final.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we want to draw out the blood slowly or a little bit, one scarification is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a great deal of blood, we will make many scars.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure, and find that the blood is thick: then it is necessary to incise deeply with a scarification, and the equal end of the scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered from oils at the position of Wind-sores, and what should a wind-sores patient beware.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that person whose skin is thick, hard, and dark, and whose pores are tight, it is necessary that the areas of Wind-sores be anointed with open, gentle, resolving oils; if in the time of summer, such as oil of alkeiri, or oil of violet, or oil made from sweet almonds, or oil from cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then oil of narcissus, or oil of lily, or oil of chamomile, or sabine oil; and similar things.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If the excess is thick and cold: then oil should be of amaranth, or oil of balsam, or oil of white poppy, or oil of anethum; and similar things.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If the wind-sores patient is of large pores and tender flesh: then it is necessary to prohibit them from oil, and it is necessary that those with such wind-sores wash the areas Ventosarum after ventosation with rose water, or cold water, or sour water, or cucumber water, or purslane water; and similar things.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of much moisture, should wash the wind-sores with vinegar, or with water of myrtle, and sumac; and similar things.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whoever has thick excesses should wash their wind-sores with old wine, or with water of sammosus, or a decoction of anise, or chamomile; and similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary to beware of inflammation in the bathhouse, or near the bathhouse, indeed it is necessary that it be administered after exiting the bathhouse for an hour, or two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And one should not sleep after inflammation.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is it that ought to be regulated with the Venosandus or Phlebotomatus before inflammation?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that it is necessary to consider first: then if the Venosandus or Phlebotomatus is choleric and prevails over his blood's sharpness and inflammation: then it is necessary that he take cooling remedies, such as pomegranate juice: and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and sycamore leaf, and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And give him foods such as eggs, old meat of sheep, and cooked foods with wild herbs: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And to one whose complexion is cold, it is necessary that he takes in his drink a syrup made from honey or almond or sycamore seed: and let him take a medium-sized fragrant wine, which is between old and new: and let him be advised to use moderation with food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And give him foods such as eggs, and small birds: and sparrows, that is, small birds; and he should also take dove's eggs.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on the day of inflammation and phlebotomy be more than food: and it is necessary to give in the drink certain things to some people one hour before breakfast, or medicine made from moss, that is, muscata, or alesselithe before inflammation; and before or after phlebotomy, so that the principal members may be strengthened and the blood may be thinned.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And one should not take it with a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	A treatise on Inflammation without Scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Those wounds that are without scarification are the ventosas which are placed on the liver, spleen, podagra, and on the belly, navel, and places of kidneys, and pithed anchae: for these members do not suffer scarification upon themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought through them, except by attraction of blood from member to member: just as we place a ventosa on the breasts in illness of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to remove from the member cold and congested blood in the member: just as we place a ventosa on the belly and navel.
